newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil civil service reform votes delayed.
newsitem.headline: Brazil civil service reform votes delayed.

text.p: Leaders of government-allied parties in the Brazilian Congress on Tuesday agreed to put off a lower house panel vote on amendments to a bill reforming the civil service, chief whip Benito Gama said.
Gama told reporters the vote on the 21 amendments had been delayed until Wednesday due to a lack of time.
He also said government parties had agreed to withdraw any amendments proposed by their deputies, totalling seven.
The panel last week approved the civil service bill, one of the key planks of the government's fiscal reforms, but left the voting on proposed amendments to later.
The bill sets a $10,800 a month salary ceiling for public servants and allow states to sack staff if their payroll exceeds 60 percent of net annual receipts.
It still has to pass through the Chamber floor twice before going to the Senate for two rounds of voting.
